intro: Biophytum huilense, commonly known as the Huilense false shamrock, is a flowering plant native to South America, particularly Ecuador. It belongs to the family Malvaceae, which includes cotton and hibiscus, and is characterized by its hairy stems and palmate leaves. The plant produces small, pale yellow flowers that bloom in clusters, typically during the rainy season. It thrives in moist, shaded environments and is often found in montane forests. Due to its ornamental value and limited distribution, it is considered a rare and ecologically significant species.
